item.description:
WHERE: DCR HATCH SHELL, Boston - on the Charles River.

http://www.mass.gov/d...

PRICE: Free

FOOD: Bring your own food in a cooler or bag (no cooking or alcohol allowed, sorry), or use the concession stand at the Hatch Shell. (I will probably get a "snack" from Chinatown after work and take it with me).

SEATING: Bring a beach towel, blanket - if you have a small, "portable" camping chair you like to use, great - bring that!

WHY FREE? Summers in Boston include free concert series on Wednesday evenings at the "Hatch Shell" organized by the Landmarks Festival.
http://www.landmarkso...

WESTERN CLASSICAL MUSIC? HOW DOES THAT CONNECT WITH CHINA?? Well, the concert isn't about Chinese culture, but China, for me, is about the sounds of life - people speaking in musical tones, people making language and food dance, and people drawing magical characters on paper that become even more magical sounds when read.

So, bring yourself and guests if you like - meet me near the entrance and we'll grab a spot for the group. This place fills up with people fast, so try to be on time.

DIRECTIONS: Red Line to Charles Street/MGH Station - walk the footbridge over Storrow Drive to the Charles River side - west along Storrow Drive - the Hatch Shell is not far. About 15 minutes walking between the station and the Shell.

Green Line is a bit more time and energy - take to Arlington Street Station - walk along Arlington Street/Public Gardens to Beacon Street - cross over Beacon Street - take Arthur Fiedler foot bridge over Storrow Drive to the Hatch Shell. About 15-20 minutes walking from the station.

http://maps.google.co...


ADELE'S LINK TO HATCH SHELL IF YOU WANT IT:

http://chinese.meetup...



*******************************
WHO IS PERFORMING: Youth Orchestra of America http://yoa.org/...

HOW DID I CHOOSE THIS PERFORMANCE? A LONG time ago, I played cello. I've enjoyed watching Benjamin Zander do so much work with young performers over the years and this orchestra is a good example. http://www.benjaminza...

Also, Dvorak and Bernstein wrote great music here in the U.S. - in fact, Bernstein was born about 20 miles north of Boston in Lawrence, Massachusetts (though he wasn't here long after that!).

And then there is "Rachmaninoff's Second Piano Concerto", one of the more popular and famous of Rach's piano concerti - a lot of people consider this a romantic and "brooding" (great word for any ESL students) piece.
